Without purpose would the law have said, “they have captured and have taken to a point within their lines,” if it meant that to have made a capture is enough. ²¹ All the words of the law ought surely to be taken into account. Now a copula, this is the popular word, implies the union of the things copulated. The law which Angelus puts for· ward ordains that the thing must be safe if it is effectually in the posses· sion of the captors. And, therefore, it means that it bas been brought within the fortified lines, where at last it is safe. ⁰ The words must be understood of eflective action, as likewise the common rule requires. And so, if a statute gives a reward to one who captures a proscribed person, the meaning is when the claimant bas made an effective capture and has brought the captive before his· superior. To acquire property the Dutch are bound to have made an effective capture of it; but they have not made an effective capture of that which they have not yet brought within their fortified lines. Consequently, they have nut acquired this property. So Ripa is un our side and Angelus also supports us, pas does Jason. Ripa cites the glossator also. qNow the glossator distinctly remarks that a thing does not belong to the enemy who takes it unless it has been brought within his fortified lines.

Salycetus who is cited makes the same statement: “Notice,” he says, “that persons do not belong to the captors, until after they have been taken within the fortilied lines of the enemy, and the same thing is true of all other movable property that, before it has been brought within the fortified lines of the enemy, it does not belong 8 to them, but remains under the same ownership as before its cap· ture, for with respect to things the reasoning is the same in this case.’' Now these golden words concerning property have been at my disposal against my adversaries, who had the hardihood to treat the case of captured persons and captured things separately. ‘Fun although in this connection the laws themselves teacn the same duc· trine concerning the acquisition of ownership in both cases, and concerning postliminium in both cases, still 1 should scarcely have established my point, if I had nut brought to bear these words of Salycetus to that effect.

Now let us mention here our uther authorities. 'The other Angelus, when he finds the statement, property taken from the enemy becomes ours at once, remarks: “ Interpret this statement in ac· cordance with that law, which requires the property to be brought within fortified lines.'‘ He teaches the same doctrine with reference tu postliminium, holding that it is not enough to have escaped from the enemy unless one gets back to his own people, because the law requires the satisfaction of both conditions.
